weaken.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to make someone or something less powerful or less important, or to become less powerful
weaken.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Over the last two years the president’s position has weakened.
Changes in policy have weakened the power of the trade unions.
The absence of this witness has weakened the case against the accused.
weaken.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to make someone lose their physical strength, or to become physically weak
weaken.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Julia was weakened by her long illness.
weaken.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to make someone less determined, or to become less determined
weaken.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Such policies weaken the resolve of potential troublemakers.
When she begged him to let her stay, he weakened.
weaken.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to make a building, structure etc less strong, or to become less strong
weaken.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: The earthquake in Cairo weakened a number of structures.
weaken.translation[0].definitions[4].def: if a particular country’s money or a company’s share prices weaken, or if they are weakened, their value is reduced
weaken.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: The pound has weakened against the dollar.
weaken.translation[1].definitions[0].def: if investments, prices, currencies etc weaken, or something weakens them, they begin to fall in value
weaken.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: A combination of low US interest rates and a rising Euro will weaken the dollar.
Work stoppages will cause an alreadyweakening economy to slow further.
London shares weakened, while Frankfurt stocks finished strong.
weaken.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to make something less powerful, successful, or profitable
weaken.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: Further weakened by the recession, the airline filed for bankruptcy.
Many agencies fear that revealing the use of subcontractors may weaken their reputations as full-service shops.
